history.content:
I would say this is bad, not necessarily because it's undoable (if you work really hard it should be), but because you don't want to take two heavy coding classes together. Deadlines will get in the way of each other and you'll have weeks where you just have to code for 80 hours without a real break.

162 is definitely heavier than 152 in terms of workload (labs vs projects). I also personally found 134 to be kind of a waste of time after taking 70. It doesn't cover anything beyond 70 probability-wise and the extra stuff it does cover is all weird stuff that doesn't have applications in EECS. EE 126 is much more recommended for CS majors unless you specifically also want to double major in statistics for some reason.

Are you interested in computer architecture or systems more? Since you've taken 70, I would say that 126 + 152 should be totally doable, and 162 + 126 should be a bit on the heavier side but also fine as well. Whether you choose 152 or 162 will depend on where on the EECS stack your interests lie. But either way, a systems EECS class and a theory EECS class should pair nicely.

children.subject:
126 definitely helps with 189. 134 helps a lot less because there isn't nearly as much emphasis on modern estimation/prediction methods. Since you're prepared for 126, you might as well take it since the class is designed to best complement the other EECS classes in the ML series (126, 127, and 189). I would say 134's emphasis is on the wrong things, like hand calculating weird word problems, and will not teach you how to use a programming language to model random variables. 126 is definitely designed to teach you how to do computational probability with the built-in labs.

I think if you're going to go with (152/162) and 126, I would personally avoid taking a third class simply because you will be taking two heavier classes and adding 186 might end up being too much. That being said, 186/152/126 is definitely possible, but again I wouldn't recommend unless you're really strong at coding and are determined to work really hard next semester.

I unfortunately need to take a third technical (either a Math class or another EE/CS course) in order to graduate in time. Maybe doing a non-project-heavy course would be better though, I'll look into it. Thanks for the advice—I think I'll try doing EE126 + CS 152 + Math 113 or something.

@anon Helix, thank you for the answer! Is there a point in taking EE126 if I don't have much of an interest in probability / plans to do ML/AI? I was taking Stat 134 to satisfy a requirement. Also, I loved both architecture and systems—figured 162 was more fundamental but 152 is only in the spring and since I was planning on doing 189 next spring, I didn't want to overlap 152/189. 

Do you think 186 + 126/Stat 134 + CS 152 is a good combo instead?

Thanks again!

<md>I'm thinking about taking CS 152 next semester but I'm not too sure of what level of knowledge I should possess before getting to the class. Anon Poet what classes have you done for the preparation? For me, I'm currently taking CS 61C, and I pretty like the materials so far and feel like did pretty well from the Total Course Point Autograder, but I have the stereotype that people who take 152 are mostly juniors or seniors (I'm now a sophomore) and you require more experience with computers before diving into 152.</md>

history.content:
Does the schedule above sound doable?

I previously took 61A/70, 16A/61B/170, 61C (over the summer), and am now in 161/188/Math 110. My workloads have been fine and I am happy with my grades so far.

I have heard that workload wise 162 > 161, 152 > 188, and Stat134 > Math110—can anyone speak as to whether these are true? Is this schedule not recommended?
history.subject: CS 162 + CS 152 + Stat 134
